title: James Kelleher
text:
James Francis "Jim" Kelleher, (October 2, 1930 – June 2, 2013) was a <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> politician and retired senator.
Born in <a href="Sault%20Ste.%20Marie%2C%20Ontario">Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario</a>, he received a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">B.A.</a> degree in 1952 from <a href="Queen%27s%20University%20at%20Kingston">Queen's University</a> and an <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Law">LL.B.</a> degree in 1956 from <a href="Osgoode%20Hall%20Law%20School">Osgoode Hall Law School</a>. Kelleher was first elected to the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20Canada">House of Commons of Canada</a> in the <a href="1984%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1984 election</a> as the <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Canada">Progressive Conservative</a> <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28Canada%29">Member of Parliament</a> for <a href="Sault%20Ste.%20Marie%2C%20Ontario">Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario</a>.
He was appointed <a href="Minister%20of%20International%20Trade%20%28Canada%29">minister of international trade</a> in the first <a href="Canadian%20Cabinet">cabinet</a> of <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Canada">prime minister</a> <a href="Brian%20Mulroney">Brian Mulroney</a>. In 1986, he became <a href="Solicitor%20General%20of%20Canada">solicitor general</a> as the result of a <a href="cabinet%20shuffle">cabinet shuffle</a>, and remained so until his defeat in the <a href="1988%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1988 election</a>.
On September 23, 1990, Kelleher was appointed to the <a href="Senate%20of%20Canada">Senate of Canada</a> on Mulroney's recommendation. He retired from the <a href="upper%20house">upper house</a> upon his seventy-fifth birthday, October 2, 2005, due to the Senate's <a href="mandatory%20retirement">mandatory retirement</a> rules.
He died of heart problems in 2013.
Archives.
There is a James Kelleher <a href="fonds">fonds</a> at <a href="Library%20and%20Archives%20Canada">Library and Archives Canada</a>.
